Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Order-of-Magnitude Problems in Star Formation and Minority Representation
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0349075
Stassun
Dr. Keivan Stassun, at Vanderbilt University, will execute a multi-faceted, collaborative research plan, involving both observational and numerical research components, with the goal of addressing order-of-magnitude problems in star formation. In his research, he will address:
1. Empirical determinations of masses for low-mass pre-main-sequence stars: 2. Angular momentum evolution of young stars: 3. Interpretive 3-D computer models of protostellar environments. Leveraging extant Vanderbilt resources, this work encompasses a broad, international research program that will provide measurements of masses and angular momenta for young stars, as well as state-of-the-art computer simulations of the complex environments of protostars. These measurements will then be used in simulations to test forefront theories of star formation and early stellar evolution.

Dr. Stassun will execute a coherent, systemic education and outreach plan, integrated into the research, with the goal of addressing the order-of-magnitude under representation of minorities in astronomy and astrophysics. His work will: 1. Enhance science learning for minority K-12 students: 2. Increase professional development opportunities for K-12 science teachers, especially those teaching at minority high-schools: 3. Train a cadre of minority undergraduate and Masters-level students for PhD study in astronomy and astrophysics: 4. Prepare graduate students for their future roles integrating research and education. This ambitious plan will be made possible by working in partnership with nearby Fisk University, an Historically Black University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project has combined research with education and outreach to address two major, unresolved problems in astronomy. The first has to do with star formation, primarily with respect to measurements of stellar masses and angular momenta, the most fundamental stellar properties. Prior to the initiation of this project, accurate, empirical mass determinations for young stars were very few, as were rotation measurements in certain star-forming environments, and consequently models of early stellar evolution remained largely untested. The other problem addressed by this project is the underrepresentation of minorities in the astronomy profession. There is parallelism between this problem and the first: Minorities in astronomy are few, and proven models for increasing the production of minority astronomers are lacking.

This project has roughly tripled the known number of "benchmark-grade" eclipsing binary stars at very young ages, with which we have been able to stringently test and improve theoretical models of star formation and evolution. A key discovery was the first (and still so far only) known eclipsing binary system comprising two brown dwarfs (so-called "failed stars"), which serves as a critical benchmark for our understanding of the formation of objects with masses between those of stars and planets. 

This project has also produced a successful model for transitioning underrepresented minority students to the PhD in physics and astronomy. The Fisk-Vanderbilt Masters-to-PhD Bridge Program has since 2004 admitted 51 students, 44 of them underrepresented minorities, 55% female, and with a retention rate of 94%. Since 2006, the program has become the top awarder of Masters degrees in physics to African Americans, and in 2011 becomes the top awarder of PhDs in physics and astronomy to underrepresented minorities.
